title: TLR5 participates in the TLR4 receptor complex and biases towards MyD88-dependent 1 signaling in environmental lung injury 2
body:
Lung disease is a major contributor to morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the US alone, over 44 15% of the population suffers from lung disease, at an annual cost of 120,000 deaths, and >$50 45 billion (1-3). Environmental lung injury, e.g. through inhaled lipopolysaccharide (LPS) or elevated 46 ozone (O3) levels, exacerbates lung disease (4-7). For example, household LPS levels are directly 47 associated with asthma symptoms and asthma-related health care utilization (7). Also, sound 48 epidemiological studies suggest that for every 10 parts-per-billion (ppb) increase in O3 levels there 49 is an associated mortality increase of 0.39-0. 87% (5, 8) . It is therefore imperative to understand 50 the mechanisms of environmentally induced lung injury. 51

Innate immune activation is a major contributor to lung disease pathogenesis and 52 environmentally-induced exacerbations (9, 10). Toll-like receptors (TLRs) orchestrate the innate 53 immune response to lung injury by recognizing exogenous pathogen-or endogenous danger-54 associated molecular patterns. TLR4 is the prototypic receptor for LPS (11), which is found in 55 particulate-matter pollution and house dust (7, 12) and is a major contributor to sepsis-induced 56 lung injury (13, 14) . TLR4 also mediates inflammation and airway hyperresponsiveness after O3 57 exposure (15), triggered by release of the endogenous sugar hyaluronan (16) . 58

Regulation of TLR4 signaling is still incompletely understood. TLR4 can heterodimerize with other 59 TLR like TLR2 and TLR6 (17, 18) ; in these cases, the partner TLRs serve to expand the TLR4 60 ligand spectrum. However, until now there has not been evidence of TLR4 interaction with other 61 regulates the immune response to injury (22) (23) (24) . TLR5 plays an important role in immunity and 67 metabolism and has been implicated in processes as varied as asthma (24), antiviral defense 68 (25), ischemia-reperfusion injury (26, 27) , radiation-induced injury (22, 28) , and regulation of gut 69 immunity (23). Furthermore, known functional genetic polymorphisms in TLR5 are associated with 70 susceptibility to infections (29-31) and autoimmune disease (32). These findings suggest a 71 clinically relevant role of TLR5 in human immune regulation in the response to injury. 72

We show that TLR5 deficiency in mice significantly alters the in vivo response to TLR4 activators 73 LPS, hyaluronan and O3. Mechanistically, we show that after ultrapure LPS exposure, TLR5 co-74 immunoprecipitates with MyD88, TLR4 and LPS. The presence of TLR5 promotes formation of 75 the Myddosome, i.e. association of MyD88 and IRAK4, and biases TLR4 signaling towards the 76

MyD88 pathway. Finally, we demonstrate that human carriers of a dominant-negative TLR5 allele 77 have decreased inflammatory response to O3 exposure in vivo and LPS exposure in vitro. Our 78 results thus suggest that TLR5 participates in TLR4 signaling and modulates environmental lung 79 injury in disease-relevant exposures that lead to TLR4 activation. 80

We first investigated the effect of TLR5 on TLR4 signaling in vivo, by exposing Tlr5-deficient mice 83 or wildtype controls to LPS via intraperitoneal administration. As expected, this led to substantial 84 lung inflammation in wildtype mice, which was ameliorated in the absence of TLR5 (Fig. 1A) . 85 TLR5 deficiency also ameliorated cellular influx and lung injury as evidenced by lung lavage 86 protein (Fig. 1B) . Furthermore, expression of inflammatory cytokines in the lung was significantly 87 ameliorated in Tlr5-deficient mice (Fig. 1C) . This was largely mirrored in a reduction of 88 inflammatory gene expression in the liver (Supplementary Fig. 1A ). To ensure that our results 89

were not affected by obesity-, microbiome-or breeding-related immune perturbations, we 90 performed experiments with mice that were either purchased from a commercial vendor (using 91 C57BL/6 as controls) or bred in our NIEHS colony (using wild-type littermates as controls) and 92 treated some mice with neomycin to reduce bacterial burden in the intestinal tract. Our results did 93 not vary regardless of mouse provenance or antibiotic treatment (Supplementary Fig. 1B) . 94

To determine if the TLR5 effect on TLR4 signaling has broader biological and clinical relevance 95 in the lung, we explored TLR5-mediated effects on sterile lung injury after exposure to the ambient 96 Hematoxylin-Eosin staining of lung sections demonstrates LPS-induced lung injury is ameliorated in Tlr5-deficient (TLR5 -/-) mice. (B) Cellular lung inflammation and lung lavage protein levels are decreased in Tlr5-deficient (TLR5 -/-) mice. (C) Real time quantitative PCR analysis of inflammatory cytokines shows a significant decrease in Tlr5-deficient (TLR5 -/-) mice. N=5-8 mice per group, experiment repeated twice. Data are represented as mean ± s.e.m. and were analyzed by unpaired t test with Welch's correction * P<0.05 and ** P<0.01 between TLR5 +/+ and TLR5 -/mice. pollutant, O3. O3 exposure is associated with increased morbidity and mortality in human patients 97 with cardiopulmonary disease (5, 8); furthermore, it is now understood that TLR4 mediates the 98 development of inflammation and airway hyperresponsiveness (AHR) after O3 exposure (15). We 99 used an O3 dose that is equivalent to human exposure during a high-O3 day (33, 34). Tlr5-deficient 100 mice had ameliorated airway cytokine expression and almost abolished AHR after O3 exposure 101 ( Fig. 2A, B) . Because hyaluronan is the endogenous danger-associated molecular pattern that 102 activates TLR4 and mediates the response after O3 exposure (15, 16), we then investigated the 103 effect of TLR5 on hyaluronan signaling. Tlr5-deficient mice had substantially reduced 104 Figure 2. TLR5 deficiency ameliorates the in vivo inflammatory response to inhaled O3. (A) TNFα and IL-6 levels in the lung lavage fluid of Tlr5-deficient (TLR5 -/-) or Tlr5-competent (TLR5 +/+ ) mice 24 hours after receiving 3 ppm O3 for 3 hours by inhalation. n = 14 mice for TLR5 +/+ and n = 12 mice for TLR5 -/-, experiment repeated twice. (B) Airway physiology measurement (total respiratory resistance Rrs, tissue damping G and tissue elastance H) to indicated doses of methacholine challenge measured with flexiVent in Tlr5-deficient (TLR5 -/-) or Tlr5-competent (TLR5 +/+ ) mice 24 hours after 2ppm O3 or air (FA) exposure. n = 6 for TLR5 -/-FA and TLR5 -/-O3 and n = 7 for TLR5 +/+ FA and TLR5 +/+ O3, experiment repeated three times. Data are represented as mean ± s.e.m. and were analyzed by unpaired t test with Welch's correction * P<0.05 and ** P<0.01 between TLR5 +/+ and TLR5 -/mice exposed to O3 This article is a US Government work. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint inflammatory gene induction and significantly diminished AHR after instilled ultrapure 105 (pharmaceutical grade) hyaluronan exposure (Fig. 3A, B) . We then performed a more global 106 analysis of the TLR5 effects on TLR4 signaling. We analyzed gene expression patterns using the 107 NanoString© platform (www.nanostring.com) and utilizing the Mouse Innate Immunity Panel 108 Figure 3 . TLR5 deficiency ameliorates the in vivo inflammatory response to instilled ultrapure short-fragment hyaluronan (sHA). (A) Real time quantitative PCR gene expression of TNF-α and IL-6 in the lung tissues of Tlr5-deficient (TLR5 -/-) or Tlr5-competent (TLR5 +/+ ) mice 6 hours after exposure to vehicle (PBS) or 50 µl of 3 mg/ml short fragment HA. n = 5 for TLR5 -/-PBS and TLR5 -/-sHA and n = 6 for TLR5 +/+ PBS and TLR5 +/+ sHA. Experiment repeated once. (B) Airway physiology measurement (tissue damping G and tissue elastance H) to indicated doses of methacholine challenge measured with flexiVent 2 hours after exposure to vehicle (PBS) or 2 mg/ml sHA. n = 5 for TLR5 -/-PBS and TLR5 -/-sHA and n = 6 for TLR5 +/+ PBS and TLR5 +/+ sHA, experiment repeated twice. Data are represented as mean ± s.e.m. and were analyzed by unpaired t test with Welch's correction * P<0.05 and ** P<0.01 between TLR5 +/+ and TLR5 -/mice. This article is a US Government work. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint Codeset (Ns_Mm_Myeloid_v2.0) and focused specifically on 242 genes that were more than 2-109 fold upregulated after LPS exposure (Supplementary Table 1 

and sorted them according to magnitude of TLR5 effect. We showed that the presence or absence 111 of functional TLR5 is associated with differential regulation of immune genes in this panel. 112

Interestingly, there was a linear correlation between the magnitude of the TLR5 effect and the 113 proportion of genes that are either published or predicted to be downstream of the NFκB pathway 114 (Supplementary Figure 2C) : among the genes that were 70-90% upregulated in Tlr5-sufficient 115 mice compared to Tlr5-deficient mice, almost 90% were in the NFκB pathway, while this 116 proportion fell to 50% among the genes that were no different between genotypes. (R 2 =0.89, 117 p=0.0013). This suggested to us that TLR5 may preferentially impact gene expression 118 downstream of MyD88 activation. In aggregate, these results support that TLR5 promotes TLR4 119 signaling in several models of TLR4 activation through pathogen-or danger-associated molecular 120 patterns (PAMPs or DAMPs, i.e. LPS or hyaluronan respectively) and promotes TLR4-mediated 121 inflammation and airway hyperresponsiveness in vivo. 122 123 Genetic TLR5 deficiency in humans impacts TLR4 signaling in vitro and ex vivo. 124

We then investigated the effect of TLR5 in human TLR4 signaling. In humans, a dominant-125 negative TLR5 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) (rs5744168, TLR5 392STOP ) (29) is found with 126 a prevalence of 8-10% in Caucasians and 3% in African Americans. We hypothesized that carriers 127 of this SNP may have reduced TLR4-mediated inflammation. We used the Environmental 128

Polymorphisms Registry (35), a NIEHS-supported cohort, to recruit carriers of this allele, as well 129 as "wildtype" controls. Others have reported that whole blood from rs5744168 minor-allele carriers 130

does not differ in the response to LPS compared to "wildtype" (31), and we confirmed this finding 131 (Supplemental Figure 3A) . We believe this happens because whole blood consists of different 132 This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint cell types, which differentially express TLR5, thereby confounding the effect on TLR4 signaling. 133

We then investigated the effect of this TLR5 SNP on purified, primary monocyte-derived 134 macrophages. Macrophages from rs5744168 minor-allele carriers had a decreased response to 135 flagellin and ultrapure LPS, but not Pam3CSK4 ( TNF-α production by peripheral blood monocyte-derived macrophages from human volunteers either homozygous for the major allele (rs5744168 M/M) or carriers of the minor allele (rs5744168 M/m) for the TLR5 single nucleotide polymorphism rs5744168. Cells were exposed to 10 ng/ml ultrapure LPS or 100 ng/ml ultrapure flagellin for 24 hours and TNF-α levels were analyzed by Duoset ELISA kit. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation and analyzed by unpaired t test with Welch's correction. N=7-13 individual subjects. (B) TLR5 gene expression in alveolar macrophages from human volunteers exposed to 200 ppb O3 for 135 minutes. N=32 individual subjects. Data are presented as individual values with mean ± s.e.m. and was analyzed by Wilcoxon pairwise signed rank test. (C) Ex-vivo TNF-α production by human alveolar macrophages after exposure to air or O3 n=3 minor rs5744168 allele carriers and 20 major allele carriers. Data are represented as individual values and trends and analyzed by Wilcoxon matched-pairs signed rank test. * P<0.05

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint confirming that human TLR5 genetic variation specifically determines the response to LPS. This 137

was not due to altered expression of TLR4 or CD14, which was not changed by the rs5744168 138 genotype (Supplemental Figure 3C) . 139

We then investigated the effect of TLR5 in O3-induced inflammation in healthy human volunteers. 140

We exposed human volunteers to O3, and isolated alveolar macrophages through bronchoscopy 141 24 hours after exposure, which represents the peak of O3-induced inflammation and symptoms 142 in humans. TLR5 expression was modestly increased in alveolar macrophages of human 143 volunteers after O3 exposure (Fig. 4B , p=0.05 by Wilcoxon pairwise signed rank test). There was 144 no association between TLR5 expression and TLR4 expression after O3 exposure. We found, that 145

TNFα expression by alveolar macrophages after O3 exposure was not increased in any of the 146 TLR5-deficient individuals (rs5744168 minor-allele carriers), while it was increased in wildtype-147 allele carriers ( Fig. 4C and Supplementary Fig.3D) . 148 149 TLR5 modulates TLR4-dependent signaling. 150

To investigate the mechanistic role for TLR5 in the response to LPS-induced TLR4 activation, we 151 then compared primary bone marrow derived macrophages (BMDM) from Tlr5-deficient and -152 sufficient mice. Tlr5-deficient BMDM had significantly decreased expression of TNFα and IL-6 153 after ultrapure LPS exposure in vitro, by an average of 30-50% (Fig. 5A) . To ensure that the 154 altered response was not due to LPS contaminants despite the ultrapure preparation, we also 155 assayed Tlr4-deficient BMDM and saw no response to ultrapure LPS (Fig. 5A) . The effect of Tlr5-156 deficiency was also observed when using other sources of Tlr4 activation, such as 157

Monophosphoryl Lipid A (Supplementary Fig. 4A ). To ascertain that our observation was not 158 due to an off-target effect of genetic Tlr5 ablation on macrophage biology, we used RAW264.7 159 cells, a murine macrophage cell line, which are naturally deficient in Tlr5 (36). We transfected 160

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint these cells with a murine Tlr5 construct, or empty vector, and noted that the Tlr5-transfected cells 161 had significantly higher TNFα expression in response to ultrapure LPS (and the TLR5 ligand 162 flagellin, as expected). The TLR5-dependent effect was specific to LPS exposure, as responses 163 to poly(I:C) (TLR3 ligand), Pam3CSK4 (TLR2 ligand), and ODN (TLR9 ligand) were not affected 164 by the presence of TLR5 (Fig. 5B) . 165 166 Figure 5 . Deficiency of TLR5 reduces ultrapure LPS induced inflammatory cytokine production. (A) TNFα and IL-6 production by BMDM from Tlr5-deficient (TLR5 -/-), Tlr4-deficient (TLR4 -/-) and wild-type (C57BL/6) mice after 10 ng/mL ultrapure LPS or vehicle (media) exposure for 12 or 24 hours. N=8 per group, experiment repeated at least 5 times. (B) TNF-α secretion by nontransfected (RAW264.7), empty construct transfected (RAW264.7 + mcs) or hemagglutinintagged TLR5 construct (TLR5-HA) transfected cells (RAW264.7 + TLR5-HA) after vehicle (media) or TLR5, TLR4, TLR3, TLR2 and TLR9 agonists (100 ng/mL recombinant ultrapure flagellin (rFLA), 10 ng/ml LPS, 10 µg/ml PolyI:C, 1 µg/ml Pam3CSK4, 1µM ODN). N=8 per group, experiment repeated twice. Data are represented as mean ± s.e.m. and were analyzed by twoway analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey's post hoc test. * P<0.05, ** P<0.01, *** P<0.001. We then interrogated the effect of TLR5 on TLR4 signaling. TLR4 signals through both MyD88 169 and TRIF pathways, whereas TLR5 signals through MyD88 only (11). We therefore hypothesized 170 that TLR5 may bias the signaling response towards the MyD88 pathway. We found that, in primary 171 murine BMDMs, MyD88 co-immunoprecipitated with TLR5 after ultrapure LPS exposure (Fig.  172   6A ). This association was directly dependent upon TLR4 activation, since it was not observed in 173

Tlr4-deficient primary BMDM (Fig. 6B) . TLR4, as expected, also immunoprecipitated with MyD88 174 after LPS exposure (Fig. 6B) . Furthermore, the association of MyD88 with TLR4 and TLR5 was 175 This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint specific, since other TLR like TLR6 and TLR7 did not immunoprecipitate with MyD88 after LPS 176 exposure (Fig. 6B, 6C) . MyD88 signaling occurs through the complexing of Myd88 with IRAK-4 177 which stabilizes formation of the so-called Myddosome (37). Tlr5-deficient BMDM had decreased 178 immunoprecipitation of IRAK-4 with MyD88 (Fig. 6C) . There was also significant reduction in the 179 phosphorylation of IKKα/β, IκB, p65, JNK1/2 and ERK1/2 in Tlr5-deficient BMDMs compared with 180 wildtype cells during early activation (Fig. 7A,B, Supplementary Fig. 4B) , which is MyD88-but 181 not TRIF-dependent (38, 39). Nuclear IRF3 (a specific readout of TRIF-dependent signaling (40)) 182

was not affected in Tlr5-deficient (Supplementary Fig. 4C ). In aggregate, these results suggest 183 that TLR5 directly interacts with MyD88 after LPS exposure and enhances MyD88-dependent 184 TLR4 signaling by promoting efficient assembly of Myddosome. 185 This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint 186 TLR5 is part of the TLR4 signaling complex. 187

We then investigated whether TLR5 participates directly in the TLR4 signaling complex, or 188 whether it affects TLR4 signaling indirectly. We first evaluated whether TLR5 affects TLR4 cell 189 surface expression and trafficking using bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDM) from 190 genetically deficient or wild-type mice. There were no differences in basal levels of cell surface 191 TLR4 or CD14 between Tlr5-deficient and -sufficient BMDM, nor in LPS-induced internalization 192 of TLR4 (Supplementary Fig. 5A-D) . Because we were unable to find commercially available 193 validated antibodies against TLR4 that could be used in co-immunoprecipitation experiments, we 194 utilized an induced expression system using tagged TLR4 and TLR5 in HEK293 cells and found 195 that TLR4 and TLR5 reciprocally co-immunoprecipitated in transfected HEK293 cells (Fig. 8A) . 196

Proximity Ligation Assay (Supplementary Fig. 5E ). Furthermore, we exposed hemagglutinin tagged expressing RAW264.7 cells to biotin-tagged LPS, and (after thoroughly 199 washing the cells) could co-precipitate TLR5 with LPS (Fig. 8B) . These results suggest that TLR5 200 This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint directly participates in the TLR4 signaling complex after LPS exposure, and, in aggregate, support 201 a functional interaction of TLR5 with TLR4 in the response to environmental injury. 202

This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint

The important novel finding from our work, is that TLR5 heteromerization with TLR4 modulates 204 canonical TLR4 signaling, and biases TLR4 signaling towards MyD88. Recent evidence highlights 205 the role of molecules of the TLR4 receptor complex in modulating TLR4 signaling. For example, 206 elegant work has demonstrated that CD14, which is necessary for LPS binding to TLR4, also 207 controls TLR4 endocytosis after LPS ligation, and thus is necessary for TRIF signaling, which is 208 thought to occur in the endosomal compartment (41). Our work further suggests that TLR4 209 signaling is modulated by the addition of TLR5 to the receptor complex. Unlike CD14, TLR5 does 210 not appear to regulate LPS-induced internalization of TLR4 (Supplementary Fig. 5C ). Our 211 findings rather support a model in which TLR5 selectively promotes TLR4/MyD88 signaling at the 212 plasma membrane and is not required for CD14 regulation of the TRIF pathway. Importantly, our 213 work suggests that TLR5 regulation of TLR4 signaling is biologically significant. TLR5-deficient 214 mice had approx. 30-50% decreased cytokine expression in local and systemic LPS models of 215 lung inflammation, while airway hyperresponsiveness after ozone or hyaluronan exposure was 216 significantly reduced, and inflammatory gene induction after hyaluronan exposure was abolished. 217

It is possible that the "fine-tuning", MyD88-promoting effects of TLR5 are particularly evident in 218 lower-grade inflammation such as ozone-or hyaluronan-induced, which explains the larger impact 219 on TLR5 deficiency on human and murine inflammation after ozone exposure compared to LPS 220

Using primary murine macrophages, we demonstrate that, in the physiological state, TLR5 co-222 immunoprecipitates with MyD88 after ultrapure LPS exposure, but only in the presence of TLR4. 223

This indicates that TLR5 is recruited into the Myddosome assembly, along with TLR4, upon TLR4 224 activation. Indeed, it has been postulated that the ability of the Myddosome to form 7:4 and 8:4 225

MyD88:IRAK4 stoichiometries is a potential mechanism through which clusters of activated TLR 226 receptors can be formed and different TLR receptors can be recruited into the same assembly 227 This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint (42). Higher-order assembly of receptor complexes in lipid raft microdomains is likely to be crucial 228 in the fine-regulation of immune responses (37). Our work suggests that TLR5 may be part of the 229 higher-order receptor assembly that regulates TLR4 signaling. TLR4 is a promiscuous receptor, 230

having been found to heterodimerize with TLR2 and TLR6 (17, 18) , but the effect of 231 heteromerization until now has always been to expand the TLR4 ligand spectrum. To our 232 knowledge, this is the first work to demonstrate that TLR heteromerization may serve to modulate 233 canonical TLR signaling. 234

A recent paper supported the role or TLR5 in TLR4 signaling, showing similar effects of the 235 rs5744168 minor allele polymorphism on TNFα and IL-8 expression by human monocytes after 236 LPS exposure, and also demonstrating that TLR5 does not influence the gene expression of TLR4 237 (43), as we also show in our Supplemental Figure 5 . By contrast, that paper could not confirm 238 that TLR5 is modifying the NFκB pathway. This apparent discrepancy may be due to different 239 research methodologies: These authors used gene silencing which only resulted in approx. 50% 240 reduction of TLR5 expression, as well as reporter cell lines with transfection-induced TLR5 241 expression, as opposed to our use of primary cells with genetically knocked-out gene function. 242

Furthermore, the authors of that study did show an effect for TLR5 on NFκB when transfecting 243 with lower (more physiological) doses of TLR5 DNA (43). 244

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https: //doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint In summary, our results suggest a new model of TLR4-TLR5 complex formation in response to 245 the PAMP LPS or the DAMP hyaluronan (Fig. 9) . We propose that the hitherto accepted model 246 of TLR4 signaling through TRIF and MyD88 rather reflects the TLR5-deficient state. In TLR5-247 expressing cells, TLR5 participates in a heteromeric higher-order TLR4 receptor complex and 248 potentiates MyD88 signaling by promoting efficient assembly of the Myddosome. This also 249 suggests that exposures that induce TLR5 expression, such as DNA injury, p53 activation (21) This article is a US Government work. C57Bl/7J mice and B6.129S1-Tlr5 tm1Flv /J (TLR5-deficient) mice were purchased from the Jackson 259 Laboratory (Bar Harbor, ME). The TLR5-deficient allele was generated in the 129S1 genome and 260 subsequently backcrossed to C57BL/6 before being transferred to the Jackson Laboratory by the 261 donating investigator. When possible, wildtype littermate control mice were used in our study in 262 parallel to commercial wildtype C57BL/6J controls. To ensure that our results were not due to 263 locality-influenced microbiome changes, we repeated experiments in mice that were bred at the 264 NIEHS vivarium, as well as mice purchased from the Jackson Laboratory and studied within 1 265

week of arrival. In some experiments, mice received neomycin water to control gut microbiome. 266

Results were comparable independent of provenance or antibiotic dosing. Mice were given 267 access to water and chow ad libitum, and were maintained at a 12-hour dark-light cycle. No 268 differences in body weight were observed at the ages studied (6-12 weeks old). All experiments 269 are approved by the NIEHS Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. and were phenotyped 24 hours later. In other experiments, mice were exposed to 2 ppm ozone 276 for 3 hours, in a chamber with 20 exchanges/hour, 50-65% relative humidity and a temperature 277 of 20-25° C as previously described (16) and were phenotyped 24 hours later. Control mice 278 received filtered air in an identical setup. In other experiments, mice received 50 µl of a 3 mg/ml 279 solution of sonicated, LPS-free, pharmaceutical-grade hyaluronan with an average molecular 280 This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/792705 doi: bioRxiv preprint weight of 100-300 kDa (derived from Healon, Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, IL) or PBS vehicle 281 by retropharyngeal aspiration, and were phenotyped 2 hours later. 282 283

Airway responsiveness to 25-100 mg/ml methacholine (MCh; Sigma) was measured 24 hours 285 following O3 or 2 hours following hyaluronan challenge. Briefly, mice were anesthetized with 286 urethane (2 g/kg; Sigma), tracheotomized with a tracheal cannula (Harvard Apparatus) with Luer 287 adapter, and mechanically ventilated on a 42 °C water-heated pad at a rate of 150 breaths/min, 288 a tidal volume of 10 ml/kg and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 3 cm H2O with a 289

computer-controlled small animal ventilator (FlexiVent, Scireq, Montreal, Canada). To block 290 spontaneous breathing, mice were given pancuronium bromide i.p. (0.8 mg/kg; Sigma-Aldrich) 291 5min prior to assessment of airway responses. To measure airway responsiveness, a single-292 frequency forced oscillation waveform, followed by a broadband forced oscillation waveform 293 (matched to the animal breathing frequency) were applied using the Flexiware 7.6 software 294 default mouse inhaled dose-response script. The resulting pressure, volume, and flow signals 295 were fit to either the Single Compartment or Constant Phase model of the lung to obtain total 296 respiratory system resistance (Rrs) and elastance (Ers) or Newtonian resistance (Rn, generally 297 understood as proximal airway resistance), tissue damping (G, generally understood as 298 peripheral tissue resistance), and tissue elastance (H), respectively(46). The peak response at 299 each dose was averaged and graphed along with the average baseline measurement for each 300 group. 301 coverslips. 24h post-transfection the cells were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for 10 305 minutes at room temperature (RT) and blocked with 10% normal goat serum for 1h at RT. The 306

Tlr5-deficient BMDM were evaluated for responsiveness to flagellin and were 319 found to be unresponsive ( Supplementary Fig. 6 ) 320 321

In order to access cell surface expression of TLR4, Wildtype, Tlr4-deficient or Tlr5-deficient 323 BMDM were harvested, washed with PBS and were exposed to ultrapure LPS for 0,15,30, 60 or 324 90 minutes. Cells were washed with cold PBS and gently lifted from the culture dishes using a 325 cell lifter. Cells numbers were estimated and cells were aliquoted in 1 x 10 6 cells per tube in the 326 FACS buffer (0.5% BSA, 0.1% NaN3, and 2mM EDTA in PBS). Cells were blocked for 20 minutes 327 on ice in a blocking solution (FACS buffer, 10% species specific serum, and 1% FCR block). Cells 328 were stained using APC anti-mouse CD284 (TLR4) Antibody (clone SA15-21), anti-CD14 329 Antibody (Biolegend) or isotype controls for 30 minutes on ice. Cells were washed two times with 330 1mL FACS buffer after staining, suspended in 500 uL FACS buffer containing 1mg/mL propidium 331 iodide (to identify dead cells) and analyzed on a BD FACSAria II equipment. 332

Wildtype or Tlr5-deficient BMDM were harvested, washed once with cold PBS, and lysed for 30 335 minutes at 4°C in 1% TritonX-100, 20 mM HEPES (pH 7.4), 150 mM NaCl, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 2mM 336 EGTA, protease and phosphatase inhibitors (Roche). Cellular debris was removed by 337 centrifugation at 16,000rcf for 10 min. For immunoblotting, cell extracts were fractionated by SDS-338 PAGE and transferred to Immobilon-P transfer membranes (Millipore), using either a wet transfer 339 apparatus (Bio-Rad) or with a dry transfer system (iBlot) from Invitrogen. Immunoblot analysis 340 was performed, and the bands were visualized with HRP-coupled goat anti-rabbit, goat anti 341 mouse, or donkey anti-goat Ig as appropriate (Rockland), using the ECL Western blotting 342 detection system (GE Healthcare). Protein levels were equilibrated with the Protein Assay 343

Reagent (Bio-Rad). 344 345

For coimmunoprecipitations, cells were harvested, washed once with cold PBS, and lysed in a 347

TritonX-100-containing buffer (0.5% TritonX-100, 20 mM HEPES (pH 7.4), 150 mM NaCl, 1.5 mM 348

MgCl 2, 2mM EGTA, protease and phosphatase inhibitors (Roche). Cell extracts were incubated 349 with 1 μg of Ab (anti-HA, Sigma) or normal IgG (negative control) for 2 h, followed by incubation 350 for 12 h with 30 μl of protein G-Sepharose beads (prewashed and resuspended in lysis buffer at 351 a 1:1 ratio). After incubations, the beads were washed four times with lysis buffer, separated by 352 SDS-PAGE, and analyzed by immunoblotting. For TLR4, TLR5, TLR6 and TLR7 antibodies, 353 blocking agent was 5% BSA and antibody dilution was 1:10,000. For Myd88 antibody, blocking 354 agent was 5% milk and antibody dilution was 1:1,000. Antibodies used were TLR4: Cat#482300 355 This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. The complete details of the human exposure studies and the subject characteristics were 364 previously published(47). After obtaining informed consent through a Duke University Institutional 365

Review Board approved protocol, healthy human subjects were exposed to filtered air and ozone 366 (200 parts per billion) in a crossover challenge designed study. Exposures were for 135 minutes, 367 during which participants alternated between resting and walking on a treadmill at 2-3 mph to 368 mimic an individual performing mildly strenuous activity under ambient conditions. Ozone was 369 created from a 100% O2 source by cold plasma corona discharge (Ozotech, Yreka CA), and 370 mixed with filtered air before addition to chamber and was continuously monitored. The order of 371 filtered air or ozone exposure were randomized for every participant, with at least a 21-day 372 washout period. Approximately 20 hours after exposure, participants underwent a flexible 373 bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage. Following bronchial alveolar lavage, human alveolar 374 macrophages were isolated. After red cell lysis and counting, the macrophages were re-375 suspended in media (RPMI1640 with 10% heat-inactivated FBS, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100 376 μg/ml streptomycin) and plated in a 24 well plate at a density of 200,000 cells per well. The cells 377

were maintained in a CO2 incubator at 37º C for 2 hours. After 2 hours, the media was replaced 378 to remove non-adherent cells and then 2 hours later, the supernatant was collected and the cells 379

were harvested for RNA. RNA extraction was performed using the Fourth Edition Qiagen Protocol 380 (Qiagen, RNeasy Mini Kit, 4th edition, Valencia, CA), followed by DNase treatment (DNase I, 381

Ambion, Austin, TX) and cDNA synthesis (BioRad). RT-PCR was performed on an ABI SDS 7500 382 (Applied Biosystems) using SYBR Green Reagent (Clontec Laboratories Inc., Mountain View, 383 CA). TLR5 expression was determined in comparison to the 18-s RNA housekeeping gene and 384

The following primers were used for RT-PCR: 18s (Fwd: GTAACCCGTTGAACCCCATT, Rev: 386 CCATCCAATCGGTAGTAGCG); TLR4 (Fwd: GGCCATTGCTGCCAACAT, Rev: CAACAATCA 387 CCTTTCGGCTTTT), TLR5 (Fwd: TGTATGCACTGTCACTCTGACTCTGT, Rev: 388 AGCCCCGGAACTTTGTGACT). Human TNF-α was measured from the cell supernatants via 389 ELISA (MAX Standard Set kit, BioLegend) according to manufactures instructions. Readings were 390 taken using BMG LABTECH Omega (Software Version 1.20). In a second study, participants 391

were invited according to their rs5744168 genotype. Peripheral blood was drawn, and monocyte-392 derived macrophages isolated after 7 days in culture and exposed to ultrapure LPS or flagellin as 393 indicated. 394 395

Data are represented as mean ± s.e.m. and were analyzed depending on experimental design by 397 either analysis of variance (one-way or two-way ANOVA) followed by Tukey's post hoc test or by 398 unpaired t test with Welch's or Holm-Sidak correction as appropriate. Tlr5 gene expression and 399 TNF-α production data from ozone expose human volunteer macrophages is presented as 400 individual values and analyzed by Wilcoxon pairwise signed rank test. 401

All clinical studies described in this work were approved by the Institutional Review Boards of the 403 NIEHS and Duke University respectively. Written informed consent was received from all 404 participants prior to inclusion in the described studies. 405 406 This article is a US Government work.
